newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Nigerian navy rescues hostages on oil barge.
newsitem.headline: Nigerian navy rescues hostages on oil barge.

text.p: Twenty foreigners held hostage by youths on an oil barge in Nigeria were rescued on Thursday night when the navy boarded the vessel, diplomats said on Friday.
"The saga has been peacefully resolved," said a senior Western diplomat who monitored the hostage-taking which began on Tuesday when youths seized the barge demanding jobs.
The barge, DLB1, belongs to the French oil contracting firm ETPM which announced in Paris late on Thursday that there were no longer any unauthorised people on board.

"Throughout yesterday negotiations were held and ETPM persuaded the local community to allow the boat to go offshore," said the diplomat. "It got about 10 miles into the sea to a certain point where it was easy for the Nigerian navy to board the barge at about 11 in the night (2200 GMT)."
He said the foreigners -- 16 Frenchmen, three Britons and one American -- were well and the barge had resumed work in the oil-producing area of Nigeria.
"There was some catering aboard and they had a hot meal," he added.
A Nigerian military government statement just hours before the end denied any foreigners had been taken hostage, saying the barge had been released following the intervention of security agents.
Communities in oil-producing areas have long been restive over lack of amenities in regions responsible for Nigeria's oil wealth. Clashes with oil companies have been common.
ETPM went through a similar crisis last December when 28 foreign workers, including 10 Filipinos and nine Frenchmen, were held on a barge offshore by 60 Nigerian workers demanding higher wages.
The latest crisis began on Tuesday when the barge was seized in the Escravos area off the midwestern oil coastal town of Warri. The barge beached on Wednesday near Warri.
ETPM officials said negotiations then began to free the foreigners and the barge was allowed to sail to where the navy intervened.

"It was a very delicate situation but we told you it was going to be over soon and that is what happened," said an official. "By 12 last night (2300 GMT) the barge was back afloat and everything is now fine."
ETPM is a joint venture between French company Lyonnaise des Eaux-Dumez and McDermott International Inc MRD.N.
ETPM spokeswoman in Paris, Ariane Malzac, told French television on Thursday the Nigerian problem was linked to rivalries between local groups.
"It's an inter-community problem...The people we employ are very well-paid. The other communities know this. They would also like to be paid by us," she said.
